Hans Matson grew up in the Mormon Church
in Sweden and became a high ranking
leader who helped oversee the church
throughout Europe now he is publicly
sharing his doubts about the history and
teachings of the church so how did you
go from being in a position of helping
teach people about the faith to having
doubts about the faith when members are
using the Internet as I usually call the
crystal ball you can't hide anything
everything is there they have they found
out a lot of questions about it
especially about teachers history and of
course being a kind of a high leader in
the church I also have those questions
to me and I have to try to deal with
them and when I did that we found out
that the church as I look at it didn't
get many answers really the Church of
Jesus Christ of Latter day Saints as the
Mormon Church is formally known has
always taught that the Book of Mormon
its core scripture is historically true
but in the era of the internet church
members have access to information that
appears contradictory for example there
is no DNA evidence to support the Book
of Mormons claims that American Indians
descended from Jews or that steel swords
existed when the book says they were
used yes the Book of Mormon historical
or not the blacks and the priesthood why
did the blacks didn't have the
priesthood was it that prophet really to
its credit the church has made volumes
of documents about its founder and
Prophet Joseph Smith available to
historians but those documents reveal
things that the church doesn't teach
most of its members such as the fact
that Joseph Smith took many wives
I'm very young but when you study this
history you find that there are girls
working in Joseph Smith's home as you
can Maiden's they clean washing things
and those are the girls he married and
Emma his first wife wouldn't know about
it and for me that's terrible you just
been 1415 years and you put so much
pressure on them and you can write read
the letters but what he wrote to them
the church says it is trying to be
transparent and that believers in every
church have doubts but when mr. Matson
brought his questions to his superiors
he says they told him to stay silent
what I felt kind of sad about and I felt
I didn't really like was that this said
that you're not supposed to talk to your
wife your children you know to talk
about this issues in church
Hans Matson says he is not alone in
suffering a crisis of faith and that
there are consequences Mormons who admit
their doubts can be prohibited from
attending weddings and baptisms and
friends and family members sometimes cut
off contact really why I'm sitting here
I'm I'm here in United States because I
can see that there are so many friends
of mine members in the church that are
being hurt they have they gone through a
terrible faith Christ as I did I mean
I'm being in this for eight years and

why shall they be so hurt by that just

acceptance that is you were allowed to
